body:
Actually, I have to revert the merge request. We now get this error in the console:
```
jquery.min.js:4 GET http://localhost:5001/api/v0/pin/add?arg=/ipns/0x627306090abaB3A6e1400e9345bC60c78a8BEf57/0x627306090abaB3A6e1400e9345bC60c78a8BEf57_1/&recursive=true 403 (Forbidden)
send @ jquery.min.js:4
ajax @ jquery.min.js:4
n.(anonymous function) @ jquery.min.js:4
(anonymous) @ app.js:14
i @ jquery.min.js:2
fireWith @ jquery.min.js:2
y @ jquery.min.js:4
c @ jquery.min.js:4
XMLHttpRequest.send (async)
send @ jquery.min.js:4
ajax @ jquery.min.js:4
n.(anonymous function) @ jquery.min.js:4
getJSON @ jquery.min.js:4
init @ app.js:7
(anonymous) @ app.js:78
dispatch @ jquery.min.js:3
r.handle @ jquery.min.js:3
(index):1 Failed to load http://localhost:5001/api/v0/pin/add?arg=/ipns/0x627306090abaB3A6e1400e9345bC60c78a8BEf57/0x627306090abaB3A6e1400e9345bC60c78a8BEf57_1/&recursive=true: No 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin' header is present on the requested resource. Origin 'http://localhost:3000' is therefore not allowed access. The response had HTTP status code 403.
```

I deleted the branch pre-maturely without testing. I'll make a new branch and reintroduce your edits, and then debug them in that branch. Sorry for the trigger finger.

I think there is a better way to do this any how, and we probably don't
want *every* page being pinned, but rather allow users to pin locally
papers that they want to read, or opt-in to a full file mirroring partner.

Have you seen how good the iPhone X "portrait" mode is at taking pictures? We should all sneak to the Apple Store one day, bring a white sheet with us to hold behind us, and do some quick portrait shots with the display phones and then send them to ourselves :P I'm only half-joking.
We have got to know someone who has one right? If not I have a pixel which has a fairly good camera
Does it have the two cameras on the back, so the background can be out of focus while the foreground is in focus? That gimmick honestly makes really good portrait photos.
Just tell me which day to wear my good shirt to work.

I think for our purposes, we also need to include something about the fact that this product is dealing with people's intellectual property. I'm not sure exactly what language is optimal there, but it's double edged. We do not want to encourage pseudo-science, and at the same time we need to be welcoming of new ideas.

Another point is being mindful of the tools that we're using. It's inappropriate to spam IPFS/IPNS with a million new hashes. In this distributed world we're working in, a culture of respect for infrastructure is crucial.

I was thinking that this code of conduct would be exclusively for contributing to the development of project. I like your comments on the arXain use conduct, and how to be a responsible and respectable author, reader, and curator on the platform. Perhaps we have this document as part of the website?

I deleted my comment about the code of conduct out of a worry that unacceptable behavior was not well defined enough, without realizing there was *literally a whole section with examples of unacceptable behavior* before. Sorry for the email spam!
OK- I'm pretty sure I'm not gonna use Hugo or any other site generators, but use the Vue.js framework for the front-end to complete this issue.
In this case, should I wait on Issue #3 or accelerate?

Is it all right to hold off on it until the middle of next week? I like the format you've already established for the about page, and I'll preserve it as I transfer things to use Vue.js. I can also explain vue.js to everyone so that you can continue creating the about page with the new framework.

on the other hand, you can fill out the "About us" page with the meat of content -- the only thing I will be changing is how the HTML tags are generated. I just want to save you the effort of writing a bunch of HTML by hand, when we'll have an automated way to generate it next week.
Yeah that sounds fine to me. I'll keep working on my branch, and we can work on the eventual pull request together!
@david-hopper you've got 2/3rds approvals -- I think you're good to merge.

This looks awesome. We should definitely decide on coding conventions (Khilesh and I ran into this with different tabbing during PennApps). I think an important addition to the "Submitting Changes" section is, once we have it running, adherence to the Continuous Integration framework. Once we have Coveralls up and running, we'll be able to specify that any changes you make to the underlying logic must be covered by tests -- that is, the coverage is not allowed to decline by some x % where x < 2, for example.
I'm happy to write the language for that once we have it up and running.
I'll merge this in then, and we can fill in the details. I'll keep issue #2 open until we address all relevant open source documents.

From meeting:
- adding a README
- "how to run dev site"
- "how to modify" example page
I think this is good enough to merge, except that we need our photos!
Looks good to me
good call. let's merge first.
Addressed by PR #10

OK! I've edited the README to explain how to set up the webpage, and how to modify the pages. This is a simple first iteration. The javascript is not so modular yet, but that will be worked on this week.

This is looking great! Could you also add a note or link into the CONTRIBUTING.md file "conventions" section to make sure that UI goes in Vue components, UX in app_*.js files etc.? I think that that point the major bases will have been covered.
done.
Looks like we should investigate [headless browser testing](https://blog.logrocket.com/introduction-to-headless-browser-testing-44b82310b27c).
@bhaney this looks awesome. I hope it's OK if we wait until Tuesday to merge, just to give me some time to play around with it.

Yeah totally! I also think I will go ahead and make an “initialize
manuscript” component too today and push it to this same branch, so this
pull request will change slightly over the weekend too. Waiting until
Tuesday works well.
